The monopolizing all-powerful Zaibatsu of pre-war fame are
gone for good.
In Japan, there never will again be the equivalent of the
Rothschildsj Morgans, and Krupps. In a panel discussion
reproduced in an issue of the magazine BUNGEI SHUNJU,
Hachiroemon Mitsui, head of the Mitsui family, says that
none of the ex-^aibatsu has the financial strength to recombine
their dismembered monopolies. ’’They can’t and they shouldn’t”
remarked ex-Baron Mitsui of the 300-year-old business clan
that once spun a strong web all over Japan. For example,
at the end of the war 17 such families or combined interests
controlled 25% of the total business capital of Japan.
The United States is to give Japan Milk and Wheat for School
Lunches.
The United States will provide Japan with about 15 million
dollars in wheat and powdered milk to expand the Japanese
school lunch program, the International Cooperation Administra¬
tion announces. The program benefits more than 7 million
school children. Japan will pay the shipping costs, and
will be expected to expand the program later entirely on
its own.
